title: Q17: Question 17
content: What acoustic psychoacoustic phenomenon tricks the human brain into combining two identical sounds arriving within 35 milliseconds of each other into a single, wider sound?
expert_explanation: If a sound and its reflection arrive at your ear within exactly 1 to 35 milliseconds of each other, the brain fuses them into a single auditory image, localizing the sound based on the first arrival.

expert_quote.text: You can use the Haas effect purposefully in a mix by delaying a guitar track by 15ms and panning it hard right away from the original track. Instant width.
expert_quote.author: Psychoacoustician

explanation:
Expert Explanation: If a sound and its reflection arrive at your ear within exactly 1 to 35 milliseconds of each other, the brain fuses them into a single auditory image, localizing the sound based on the first arrival.

"You can use the Haas effect purposefully in a mix by delaying a guitar track by 15ms and panning it hard right away from the original track. Instant width."
- Psychoacoustician

title: Q18: Question 18
content: What is the industry-standard geometric physical placement required for setting up a pair of stereo near-field studio monitors?

answers.text: An exact Perfect Circle around the mix engineer's head
An Equilateral Triangle (equal perfectly matching distances between both speakers and the listener's head)
A Right Angle directly strictly pointing inwards cleanly towards each other
Placed perfectly flat closely against the strict front wall facing completely outwards

expert_explanation: Near-field monitors must physically form an equilateral triangle with the listener's head. The tweeters should physically aim slightly behind the ears to create a precise 'phantom center' stereo image.

expert_quote.text: If your listening triangle is too narrow, the stereo field collapses. If it is too wide, a hole literally appears straight down the middle of your mix.
expert_quote.author: Studio Builder

explanation:
Expert Explanation: Near-field monitors must physically form an equilateral triangle with the listener's head. The tweeters should physically aim slightly behind the ears to create a precise 'phantom center' stereo image.

"If your listening triangle is too narrow, the stereo field collapses. If it is too wide, a hole literally appears straight down the middle of your mix."
- Studio Builder

title: Q19: Question 19
content: According to the Fletcher-Munson equal-loudness contours, what is the 'ideal' standard average monitoring volume for making accurate mixing decisions without severe frequency bias?

answers.text: Absolutely silent whispering volume strictly at 30dB SPL
Roughly 80-85 dB SPL (a moderately loud conversation level)
Massive roaring concert club volume perfectly at 120dB SPL
Purely random volumes strictly changing securely every minute

expert_explanation: The Fletcher-Munson curves prove that the human ear naturally hears bass and treble better at higher volumes. Mixing around 80-85 dB SPL is where our human hearing frequency response curve is the flattest and most accurate.

expert_quote.text: If you consistently mix too quietly, you will naturally boost exactly the bass and treble far too much to compensate for human hearing.
expert_quote.author: Mastering Engineer

explanation:
Expert Explanation: The Fletcher-Munson curves prove that the human ear naturally hears bass and treble better at higher volumes. Mixing around 80-85 dB SPL is where our human hearing frequency response curve is the flattest and most accurate.

"If you consistently mix too quietly, you will naturally boost exactly the bass and treble far too much to compensate for human hearing."
- Mastering Engineer

To fundamentally decouple the speaker cabinet directly from the desk, preventing sympathetic resonances from explicitly vibrating the furniture loudly

expert_explanation: Decoupling prevents the mechanical vibrations of the speaker cabinet from traveling into the desk or stands. If the desk vibrates, it turns into a secondary uncontrolled speaker, ruining the low-end accuracy.

expert_quote.text: Always use monitor isolation pads. Sitting speakers directly on a desk without them is completely unacceptable in any professional acoustic environment.
expert_quote.author: Studio Builder

explanation:
Expert Explanation: Decoupling prevents the mechanical vibrations of the speaker cabinet from traveling into the desk or stands. If the desk vibrates, it turns into a secondary uncontrolled speaker, ruining the low-end accuracy.

"Always use monitor isolation pads. Sitting speakers directly on a desk without them is completely unacceptable in any professional acoustic environment."
- Studio Builder
